Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin. Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory. Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml. The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as: 2019-05-30-welcome.md 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images: The blog supports tags as well! And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

This is the summary of a very long blog post, Use a <!-- truncate --> comment to limit blog post size in the list view. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. This is an example document. ref : V1.23.2 danger If your seeing this, please contact the administrator.
Data type may seem complicated at first, but it's actually quite simple. In this section, we'll go over the basics of data types and how to use them.

A data type is a classification of data which tells the compiler or interpreter how the programmer intends to use the data. As human beings, we can easily identify the type of data just by looking at it. For example, if we see the number 5, we know that it's an integer. If we see the number 5.0, we know that it's a floating point number. If we see the word "Hello", we know that it's a string. But how does the computer know what type of data it is ? The answer is that the programmer tells the computer what type of data it is. We can do this by using data types.
There are 7 main data types in C : Integer (int) Floating Point (float) Character (char) Double (double) Void (void) Boolean (bool) Lets go over each one of them.

An integer is a whole number like "3" or "100". In C, an integer can be either a short, an int, or a long. Data Type Size Range short 2 bytes -32,768 to 32,767 int 4 bytes -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647 long 8 bytes -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,807

A floating point number is a number with a decimal point like "3.14" or "100.0". In C, a floating point number can be either a float or a double. Data Type Size Range float 4 bytes 1.2E-38 to 3.4E+38 double 8 bytes 2.3E-308 to 1.7E+308
A character is a single letter or symbol like "a" or "!" or "👍". In C, a character is represented by a single quote. char letter = 'a'; char symbol = '!'; char emoji = '👍';

Void is a special data type that is used to define functions that do not return a value. In C, void is represented by the keyword void. void printHello() { printf("Hello"); } In some case, void can be a data type in function parameters and take the place of any other data type. If your function can take a parameter of any type, you can use void.

A boolean is a data type that can only be true or false. In C, a boolean is represented by the keyword bool. It's very useful to make conditionnal statements. bool isTrue = true; bool isFalse = false; #include <stdio.h> #include <stdbool.h> int main() { bool isTrue = true; bool isFalse = false; if (isTrue) { write("isTrue is true
"); } else if (isFalse) { write("isFalse is true
"); } else { write("isTrue and isFalse are false
"); } return 0; }

In this tutorial, we learned about data types in C. Now you know how to declare variables and how to use them. It's can be complicated at first, but you will get used to it. If you have any questions, feel free to ask or search on the internet !

In this chapter, we will learn about control statements in C. Control statements are used to control the flow of execution of the program. The control statements are also known as conditional statements. The control statements are used to perform different actions based on different conditions.
There are three types of control statements in C. They are: if statement if-else statement switch statement
The if statement is used to execute a block of code if a given condition is true. The syntax of the if statement is: if (condition) { // code to be executed if condition is true }

int main() { int a = 10; if (a > 5) { printf("a is greater than 5"); } return 0; } That it, if the condition is true, the code inside the if block will be executed. If the condition is false, the code inside the if block will be skipped.

The if-else statement is used to execute a block of code if a given condition is true. If the condition is false, another block of code can be executed. The syntax of the if-else statement is: if (condition) { // code to be executed if condition is true } else { // code to be executed if condition is false }

int main() { int a = 10; if (a > 15) { printf("a is greater than 15"); } else { printf("a is less than or equal to 15"); } return 0; } If the condition is true, the code inside the if block will be executed. If the condition is false, the code inside the else block will be executed.

The if-else statement can be nested inside another if-else statement. The syntax of the nested if-else statement is: if (condition1) { // code to be executed if condition1 is true if (condition2) { // code to be executed if condition2 is true } else { // code to be executed if condition2 is false } } else { // code to be executed if condition1 is false }

Switch statements are used to perform different actions based on different conditions. It's an alternative to the if-else statement to avoid nested if-else statements or a lot of if-else statements. The syntax of the switch statement is: switch (expression) { case constant-expression1: // code to be executed if expression is equal to constant-expression1 break; case constant-expression2: // code to be executed if expression is equal to constant-expression2 break; case constant-expression3: // code to be executed if expression is equal to constant-expression3 break; default: // code to be executed if expression is not equal to any constant-expression }

int main() { int a = 2; switch (a) { case 1: write("a is equal to 1"); break; // break statement is used to exit the switch statement case 2: write("a is equal to 2"); break; // break statement is used to exit the switch statement case 3: write("a is equal to 3"); break; // break statement is used to exit the switch statement default: write("a is not equal to 1, 2 or 3"); } return 0; }

In this chapter, we learned about control statements in C. We learned about the if statement, if-else statement and switch statement. We also learned about nested if-else statements and the break statement in the switch statement. If you want to learn more about good practices in statements, don't hesitate to talk and search for more information.
danger This section is important to understand the concepts of C programming language. Please read it carefully.

To start coding in C, you need to know the basics of the language. This section will teach you the basics of the C programming language. You will learn about the syntax of the language, the data types, and the operators. You will also learn about the control statements and functions. What is C?​ C is a general-purpose, high-level programming language that was originally developed by Dennis Ritchie between 1969 and 1973 at Bell Labs. C was originally first implemented on the DEC PDP-11 computer in 1972. Why C?​ C is a middle-level language, as it comprises both high-level and low-level language features. The language was designed to be compiled using a relatively straightforward compiler, to provide low-level access to memory, to provide language constructs that map efficiently to machine instructions, and to require minimal run-time support. These design goals make C a suitable language for implementing operating systems or other system software.

You have to read the following topics in order to understand. It a lot of information, but it is important to understand the concepts of C programming language. Hello World Variables Data Types Operators Control Statements Functions [Arrays] [Pointers] [Strings] [Structures] [Unions] [Enumerations] [Input and Output] [Preprocessor] [Command Line Arguments] [Recursion] [Memory Management] [File Handling] [Data Structures] [Advanced Topics]
In this tutorial, we will learn how to write a simple C program that prints "Hello, World!" to the screen. We will also discuss the basic structure of a C program and how to compile and run it.
Let's start by writing a simple C program that prints "Hello, World!" to the screen. Here's the complete program: int main(void) { write(1, "Hello, World!", 13); return 0; }

We define the main function. This is the entry point of our program. int main(void) We call the write function to print "Hello, World!" to the screen. write(1, "Hello, World!", 13); The write function takes three arguments: the file descriptor of the output stream, the string or variable to print, and the length of the string. The file descriptor 1 refers to the standard output stream, which is the screen. You can also use 2 to refer to the standard error stream like segfaults. The string "Hello, World!" is the text we want to print. The length 13 is the number of characters in the string. This is very important, because the write function doesn't know how long the string is, so we have to tell it. We return 0 to indicate that the program ran successfully. return 0;
documents.s: let's go through the code step by step:

documents.t: Now that we have written our program, we need to compile it. To compile a C program, we need to use a compiler. The compiler takes the source code of the program and converts it into machine code, which is a series of instructions that the computer can understand. The compiler also performs some checks to make sure that the program is valid. To compile our program, we will use the gcc compiler. The gcc compiler is the default compiler on most Linux distributions. To compile our program, we will use the following command: gcc hello.c -o hello To run the program, we will use the following command: ./hello

In this tutorial, we learned how to write a simple C program that prints "Hello, World!" to the screen. We also discussed the basic structure of a C program and how to compile and run it. If you understand all we talk about in this tutorial, you are ready to move on to the next tutorial, which will teach you how to use variables in C and data types.

Variables allow you to store and manage data in your program by assigning names to values. Imagine a variable as a container that holds a specific value. You can reference this container by its assigned name, update its contents by replacing the current value with a new one, or retrieve the stored value to use it in your program.

In order to use a variable in your program, you must first declare it. This is done by using this : int myVariable; Now we declare a variable called myVariable of type int. This means that the variable can only hold integer (number) values. If you want to store an other type of value, you must declare a variable with this type : float myVariable; // for floating point numbers, like 3.14 char myVariable; // for characters, like 'a' bool myVariable; // for booleans, true or false

Once you have declared a variable, you can assign a value to it. This is done by using the = operator : int myVariable = 5; // myVariable now holds the value 5 For other types of value, you can assign a value like this : float myVariable = 3.14; // myVariable now holds the value 3.14 char myVariable = 'a'; // myVariable now holds the value 'a' bool myVariable = true; // myVariable now holds the value true
documents.s: Assigning a value to a variable

documents.t: Now that you have declared and assigned a value to a variable, you can use it in your program. You can use it in a write statement : int myVariable = 5; write(myVariable); // will print 5 You can also use it in a read statement, to ask the user to enter a value : int myVariable; read(myVariable); // will ask the user to enter a value, and store it in myVariable write(myVariable); // will print the value entered by the user
You can update the value of a variable by assigning a new value to it. This is done by using the = operator : int myVariable = 5; myVariable = 10; // myVariable now holds the value 10

When you declare a variable, you must give it a name. This name must follow some rules : It must start with a letter or an underscore (_) It can only contain letters, numbers and underscores (_) It cannot be a reserved keyword (like int, float, char, bool, if, else, while, for, write, read, true, false) It cannot be the same as a function name

In this tutorial, you have learned how to declare, assign and use variables in your program. You can now use variables to store and manage data in your program. Don't forget to check out the next tutorial, where you will learn all data types more in depth.

In this tutorial, we are going to learn about functions in C. Functions are a very important part of C programming. Functions are used to perform a specific task, we can also use them to split our program into multiple part. This is a very important part of the tutorial, so make sure you understand everything.

A function is a block of code that performs a specific task. Print text, calculate a value, etc. There are used to split our program into multiple parts and know where to start and where to end. This give us a better overview of our program and make it easier to understand.

To create a function, we need to use a data type, a name and a set of parenthesis. The data type is the type of data that the function will return. if we return nothing, we can use void. The name is the name of the function. The parenthesis are used to pass arguments to the function. The function will be closed with a curly bracket. data_type name(char arguments) { // code return data_type; }

To call a function, we need to use the function name and pass the arguments. The arguments are the data that we want to pass to the function. This is optional but useful. void function(char arguments) { write(arguments); } void main() { char arguments = "Hello World"; function(arguments); }

To return a value from a function, we need to use the return keyword. This can be used to return a value from a function if you want to use it later. int add(int a, int b) { return a + b; } void main() { int a = 5; int b = 10; int result = add(a, b); write(result); } Output​ 15
documents.s: How to return a value from a function ?

documents.t: To pass arguments to a function, we need to use the function name and pass the arguments. The arguments are the data that we want to pass to the function. This is optional but useful. void function(char arguments) { write(arguments); } void main() { char arguments = "Hello World"; function(arguments); }
documents.s: How to pass arguments to a function ?

documents.t: To pass arguments by reference, we need to use the & operator. This will pass the address of the variable to the function. Reminder : The & operator is used to get the address of a variable. Where the data is stored. The * operator is used to get the value of a variable. With the address of the variable. void function(int *a) { *a = 10; } void main() { int a = 5; function(&a); write(a); } Output​ 10
documents.s: How to pass arguments by reference ?

documents.t: In this tutorial, we learned about functions in C. We learned how to create a function, how to call a function, how to return a value from a function, how to pass arguments to a function and how to pass arguments by reference. This is a very important part of the tutorial, so make sure you understand everything. Have a nice coding session and see you in the next tutorial !

There you go, if your are here, you are probably a developer, and you want to learn some Tip for your next project. This is the place for you, we will try to give you some tips and tricks to make your life easier.

This is a guide for student, developper, and everyone who want to learn some skills to progress in his project. We will try to cover as much as we can, but we will focus on the most important things. We will try to cover the following topics: Epitech Project C Programming Language CSFML Graphics Library Ncurse Library UNIX System Programming Criterion Unit Testing Framework Git Version Control System MakeFile Build System Docker Containerization System Bash Shell Scripting Language

For a better experience, we recommend to follow the guide in the right order to understand the concepts. But if you want to jump to a specific topic, you can use the sidebar to navigate through the guide. Your ready to start ? Let's go !
Operators are special symbols that perform specific operations on one, two, or three operands, and then return a result.

C language is rich in built-in operators and provides the following types of operators: Arithmetic operators Relational operators Logical operators Bitwise operators Assignment operators Misc operators

Arithmetic operators are used in mathematical expressions in the same way that they are used in algebra. C language supports the following arithmetic operators: Operator Description Example + Addition a + b - Subtraction a - b * Multiplication a * b / Division a / b % Modulus a % b ++ Increment a++ -- Decrement a--

Relational operators are used in logical statements to determine the relationship between two entities. C language supports the following relational operators: Operator Description Example == Checks if the values of two operands are equal or not, if yes then condition becomes true. (a == b) != Checks if the values of two operands are equal or not, if values are not equal then condition becomes true. (a != b) > Checks if the value of left operand is greater than the value of right operand, if yes then condition becomes true. (a > b) < Checks if the value of left operand is less than the value of right operand, if yes then condition becomes true. (a < b) >= Checks if the value of left operand is greater than or equal to the value of right operand, if yes then condition becomes true. (a >= b) <= Checks if the value of left operand is less than or equal to the value of right operand, if yes then condition becomes true. (a <= b)

Logical operators are used to determine the logic between variables or values. C language supports the following logical operators: Operator Description Example && Called Logical AND operator. If both the operands are non-zero, then the condition becomes true. (a && b) || Called Logical OR Operator. If any of the two operands is non-zero, then the condition becomes true. (a \|\| b) ! Called Logical NOT Operator. Use to reverses the logical state of its operand. If a condition is true, then Logical NOT operator will make false. !(a && b)

Bitwise operators act on operands as if they were string of binary digits. It operates bit by bit, hence the name. C language supports the following bitwise operators: Operator Description Example & Binary AND Operator copies a bit to the result if it exists in both operands. (a & b) | Binary OR Operator copies a bit if it exists in either operand. (a \| b) ^ Binary XOR Operator copies the bit if it is set in one operand but not both. (a ^ b) ~ Binary Ones Complement Operator is unary and has the effect of 'flipping' bits. (~a) << Binary Left Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved left by the number of bits specified by the right operand. (a << 2) >> Binary Right Shift Operator. The left operands value is moved right by the number of bits specified by the right operand. (a >> 2)

Assignment operators are used in C to assign values to variables. C language supports the following assignment operators: Operator Description Example = Simple assignment operator c = a + b += Add AND assignment operator c += a -= Subtract AND assignment operator c -= a *= Multiply AND assignment operator c *= a /= Divide AND assignment operator c /= a %= Modulus AND assignment operator c %= a <<= Left shift AND assignment operator c <<= 2 >>= Right shift AND assignment operator c >>= 2 &= Bitwise AND assignment operator c &= 2 ^= Bitwise exclusive OR and assignment operator c ^= 2 |= Bitwise inclusive OR and assignment operator c \|= 2

In this tutorial, you have learned about operators in C programming language. It's okay if you don't understand everything in this tutorial. You will learn more about how to use operators in C programming language in the following tutorials. You can come back to this tutorial anytime if you need to look up something.

CSFML (C Simple and Fast Multimedia Library) is a simple and easy-to-use multimedia library written in C language. It provides a set of functions for creating 2D graphics, playing audio and video, handling input events, and managing windows. In this documentation, we will discuss the basic usage of CSFML.

You can also install CSFML using the package manager of your operating system. Here are the packages for some popular operating systems: - Arch Linux: csfml - Debian: libcsfml-dev - Fedora: CSFML-devel - Gentoo: media-libs/csfml - Mac OS X: csfml - Ubuntu: libcsfml-dev
documents.s: Installing CSFML using a package manager

documents.t: To use CSFML in your C programs, you need to install it first. Follow these steps to install CSFML: Download the latest version of CSFML from the official website Extract the downloaded archive to a folder on your computer. Open a terminal or command prompt and navigate to the folder where you extracted CSFML. Run the following commands: cmake . make sudo make install CSFML should now be installed on your system.

To use CSFML in your C programs, you need to include the appropriate header files and link your program with the CSFML libraries. Here's an example of a simple CSFML program that creates a window and draws a circle: #include <SFML/Graphics.h> int main(void) { sfVideoMode mode = {800, 600, 32}; sfRenderWindow* window = sfRenderWindow_create(mode, "My window", sfResize | sfClose, NULL); sfCircleShape* circle = sfCircleShape_create(); sfCircleShape_setRadius(circle, 50.f); sfCircleShape_setFillColor(circle, sfRed); while (sfRenderWindow_isOpen(window)) { sfEvent event; while (sfRenderWindow_pollEvent(window, &event)) { if (event.type == sfEvtClosed) { sfRenderWindow_close(window); } } sfRenderWindow_clear(window, sfWhite); sfRenderWindow_drawCircleShape(window, circle, NULL); sfRenderWindow_display(window); } sfCircleShape_destroy(circle); sfRenderWindow_destroy(window); return 0; }

We include the SFML/Graphics.h header file. This header file contains all the functions and types needed to create a graphical application with CSFML. #include <SFML/Graphics.h> We define the main function. This is the entry point of our program. int main(void) We create a video mode object. This object defines the size and the color depth of the window we will create. The function take three arguments: the width, the height, and the color depth. sfVideoMode mode = {800, 600, 32}; We create a window object. This object represents the window we will create. sfRenderWindow* window = sfRenderWindow_create(mode, "My window", sfResize | sfClose, NULL); We create a circle shape object. This object represents the circle we will draw. sfCircleShape* circle = sfCircleShape_create(); We set the radius of the circle to 50 pixels. The radius is the distance from the center of the circle to its edge. He is in pixels. sfCircleShape_setRadius(circle, 50.f); We set the fill color of the circle to red. sfCircleShape_setFillColor(circle, sfRed); We enter the main loop of our program. This loop will run until the window is closed. while (sfRenderWindow_isOpen(window)) We poll for events. This function checks if any events have been triggered since the last time we called it. while (sfRenderWindow_pollEvent(window, &event)) We check if the event is a close event. If it is, we close the window. if (event.type == sfEvtClosed) { sfRenderWindow_close(window); } We clear the window with a white color. This function fills the entire window with the given color. sfRenderWindow_clear(window, sfWhite); We draw the circle to the window. The NULL argument is a pointer to a render states object. We will discuss this object in a later tutorial. sfRenderWindow_drawCircleShape(window, circle, NULL); We display the contents of the window on the screen. If you don't call this function, nothing will be displayed on the screen. sfRenderWindow_display(window); We destroy the circle shape object. This is important because it frees up the memory used by the circle. (If you don't do this, you will have a memory leak.) sfCircleShape_destroy(circle); We destroy the window object. This is important because it frees up the memory used by the window. (If you don't do this, you will have a memory leak.) sfRenderWindow_destroy(window); We return 0 from the main function. This is important because it tells the operating system that the program ran successfully. return 0;
documents.s: Let's go through the code step by step:

documents.t: To compile this program, you need to link it with the CSFML libraries. Here's an example of a Makefile that compiles the program above: all: gcc -o my_program my_program.c -lcsfml-graphics -lcsfml-window -lcsfml-system
Now that you know how to use CSFML, it's time to write your own programs. You can find more examples in the [examples]
